projectDesc.p: This document is part of a wider project to make the contents of Town, a collection of poetry and photography by Annemarie Ní Churreáin and Rich Gilligan, available as TEI-compliant machine-readable texts. The transcription and encoding of these materials has been undertaken with the kind permission of Jamie Murphy, who imprint The Salvage Press, published the original printed editions of Town in 2018.

lg.l: I
I am all source when you lay me down in June

and whisper
I want you here.
I am both here and many-streamed
among the fjords and meadows
muck-pooled and purpled, peat-dreaming
tunnels, cotton slopes.
But how to speak yet of rowing boats?
How to say the testimony of a swan?
A river is a thing of parts.
II

l.hi: Abhainn na Life, Anna Livia, An Ruirthech.

lg.l: Beneath the tongue I pulse
shifting sediments, taking shape.
I pass under an unmarked bridge
and move the pale blonde watergrass.
A reservoir does the work of Gods.
As within me wild creatures swim,
I speed against the blind curve of banks,
Even Canaan's daughter disappeared.
III
Here are the ways in which I aim to outlive
father, the seedling dreams of mother,
bruising forth, blurring static over flat plains,
a question unreplied.
Bring me to your lips and I can say only
the love-word soon.
You cannot keep me from this route, I must
take you in my arms.
What the river carries, the river knows.
IV
Lover, women, girl these are the names
that you call me through darkness
but in the ling marrow of my bones a drowning
repeats
and falls away and repeats.
All this shadow, all this reckoning.
Let me swear in the language of the water
as honest as an oar
V
Heart and the land opens thirteen times to reveal
beyond terminals,
unbright ships, tanks purring in the port
beneath a plural sky. This is how I arrive to you.
Liffey, mouth, I: now one.
The twisted river of my history unmade.
Hold me like the holiest of water
carefully and with intent. Hold me
